question: Section 201 07 (a)
sols_html:
If we define

\(U = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} , \ \ \Sigma = \begin{bmatrix} \sigma_1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & \sigma_2 & 0 \end{bmatrix} , \ \ V = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} & 0 \end{bmatrix}\)

Matrices U and V are orthogonal matrices because their columns form a basis of orthonormal vectors, all the entries are real, and the sum of the column entries are equal to 1.

Matrix \(\Sigma\) is a diagonal matrix.

A property of orthogonal matrices is that they have no effect on the length of a norm.

\(\displaystyle ||A|| = ||\Sigma|| = \sigma _1\)

The norm of matrix A is equal to the largest value on the diagonal of matrix \(\Sigma\).

The rank of A is equal to the number of pivot columns in the diagonal matrix \(\Sigma\):

\(\dim(A) = 2\)
sols_latex:
If we define

$U = \begin{bmatrix}
0 & 1
\\ 1 & 0
\end{bmatrix}
, \ \ \Sigma = \begin{bmatrix}
\sigma_1 & 0 & 0
\\ 0 & \sigma_2 & 0
\end{bmatrix}
, \ \ V = \begin{bmatrix}
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} & 0
\\ 0 & 0 & 1
\\ -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} & 0
\end{bmatrix}$

Matrices \emph{U} and \emph{V} are orthogonal matrices because their
columns form a basis of orthonormal vectors, all the entries are real,
and the sum of the column entries are equal to 1.

Matrix $\Sigma$ is a diagonal matrix.

A property of orthogonal matrices is that they have no effect on the
length of a norm.

$\displaystyle ||A|| = ||\Sigma|| = \sigma _1$

The norm of matrix \emph{A} is equal to the largest value on the
diagonal of matrix $\Sigma$.

The rank of \emph{A} is equal to the number of pivot columns in the
diagonal matrix $\Sigma$:

$\dim(A) = 2$

<math>U = \begin{bmatrix}
0 & 1
\\ 1 & 0
\end{bmatrix}
, \ \ \Sigma = \begin{bmatrix}
\sigma_1 & 0 & 0
\\ 0 & \sigma_2 & 0
\end{bmatrix}

\\ 0 & 0 & 1
\\ -\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} & \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} & 0
\end{bmatrix}</math>

Matrices ''U'' and ''V'' are orthogonal matrices because their columns form a basis of orthonormal vectors, all the entries are real, and the sum of the column entries are equal to 1.

Matrix <math>\Sigma</math> is a diagonal matrix.

A property of orthogonal matrices is that they have no effect on the length of a norm.

<math> \displaystyle ||A|| = ||\Sigma|| = \sigma _1</math>

The norm of matrix ''A'' is equal to the largest value on the diagonal of matrix <math>\Sigma</math>.

The rank of ''A'' is equal to the number of pivot columns in the diagonal matrix <math>\Sigma</math>:

<math> \dim(A) = 2 </math>
statement_html:
Suppose that the matrix A has the following singular value decomposition:

\[\begin{aligned} A = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \sigma_1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & \sigma_2 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ -1\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

where \(\sigma_1 \geq \sigma_2 \geq 0\).

(a) What are \(\|A\|\) and rank(A)?
